hypothesis: Vice President Biden and President Obama assembled a pandemic playbook to make sure that America was prepared and protected. The Trump administration disbanded the pandemic response team that was given to them.
explanation_1: It seems from the 3rd QA that the group was indeed disbanded therefore the claim is supported
speaker: Eva Longoria Bastón

answers.answer: Yes
answers.boolean_explanation: Through the Obama administration, the NSC devised the guide — officially called the Playbook for Early Response to High-Consequence Emerging Infectious Disease Threats and Biological Incidents, but known colloquially as "the pandemic playbook" — across 2016. The project was driven by career civil servants as well as political appointees, aware that global leaders had initially fumbled their response to the 2014–2015 spread of Ebola and wanting to be sure that the next response to an epidemic was better handled.

questions.question: Did Vice President Biden and President Obama assemble a pandemic playbook to make sure that America was prepared and protected?

answers.answer: No
answers.boolean_explanation: The Trump administration was briefed on the playbook’s existence in 2017, said four former officials, but two cautioned that it never went through a full, National Security Council-led interagency process to be approved as Trump administration strategy.

questions.question: Did President Donald Trump utilize the pandemic playbook?

answers.answer: Yes
answers.boolean_explanation: The document rested with NSC officials who dealt with medical preparedness and biodefense in the global health security directorate, which the Trump administration disbanded in 2018, four former officials said.

questions.question: Did President Donald Trump disband the pandemic response team that was given to him?

answers.answer: “We are aware of the document, although it’s quite dated and has been superseded by strategic and operational biodefense policies published since,” the official said. “The plan we are executing now is a better fit, more detailed, and applies the relevant lessons learned from the playbook and the most recent Ebola epidemic in the [Democratic Republic of the Congo] to COVID-19.”

questions.question: Why did the Trump administration not utilize the pandemic playbook?

answers.answer: Yes
answers.boolean_explanation: a president can choose cabinent members he chooses to work with

questions.question: is it normal for  a new president to set up their own working team

Answer 1:  Yes 
 
Question 2:  Did President Donald Trump utilize the pandemic playbook? 
Answer 2:  No 
 
Question 3:  Did President Donald Trump disband the pandemic response team that was given to him? 
Answer 3:  Yes

Answer 4:  “We are aware of the document, although it’s quite dated and has been superseded by strategic and operational biodefense policies published since,” the official said. “The plan we are executing now is a better fit, more detailed, and applies the relevant lessons learned from the playbook and the most recent Ebola epidemic in the [Democratic Republic of the Congo] to COVID-19.” 
 
Question 5:  is it normal for  a new president to set up their own working team 
Answer 5:  Yes

questions.question: What effect has the Covid-19 Pandemic had on China - Middle East relations?

answers.answer: Iran Projected China’s national flag and words of support on to its famous Azadi Tower
Chinese government has expressed sincere thanks to its counterparts in the Gulf and started sending medical aid to Iran, the worst affected country in the region.

hypothesis: COVID Outbreak Discovered in Oregon Minks
explanation_1: Minks tested positive for covid-19
speaker: Center for Biological Diversity ‏

answers.answer: Minks were infected following exposure from infected humans. Minks can act as a reservoir of SARS-CoV-2, passing the virus between them, and pose a risk for virus spill-over from mink to humans. People can then transmit this virus within the human population. Additionally, spill-back (human to mink transmission) can occur. It remains a concern when any animal virus spills in to the human population, or when an animal population could contribute to amplifying and spreading a virus affecting humans. As viruses move between human and animal populations, genetic modifications in the virus can occur. These changes can be identified through whole genome sequencing, and when found, experiments can study the possible implications of these changes on the disease in humans.

questions.question: Can Mink contract Covid_19?

answers.answer: ink are highly susceptible to SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19. Pair this fact with the crowded, filthy conditions on fur farms, and a disastrous and deadly public health situation is inevitable.

questions.question: Are minks susceptible to covid_19 ?

answers.answer: Mink on fur farms in Michigan, Oregon, Utah, and Wisconsin have tested positive for COVID-19. Research now shows that infected mink may contract the virus from humans and can transmit SARS-CoV-2 back to humans. This cycle has led to the development of mutated strains of the virus. Wild mink have also tested positive for COVID-19 in Utah.

questions.question: Was COVID Outbreak Discovered in Oregon Minks?A

premise:
Question 1:  Can Mink contract Covid_19? 
Answer 1:  Minks were infected following exposure from infected humans. Minks can act as a reservoir of SARS-CoV-2, passing the virus between them, and pose a risk for virus spill-over from mink to humans. People can then transmit this virus within the human population. Additionally, spill-back (human to mink transmission) can occur. It remains a concern when any animal virus spills in to the human population, or when an animal population could contribute to amplifying and spreading a virus affecting humans. As viruses move between human and animal populations, genetic modifications in the virus can occur. These changes can be identified through whole genome sequencing, and when found, experiments can study the possible implications of these changes on the disease in humans. 
 
Question 2:  Are minks susceptible to covid_19 ? 
Answer 2:  ink are highly susceptible to SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19. Pair this fact with the crowded, filthy conditions on fur farms, and a disastrous and deadly public health situation is inevitable. 
 
Question 3:  Was COVID Outbreak Discovered in Oregon Minks?A 
Answer 3:  Mink on fur farms in Michigan, Oregon, Utah, and Wisconsin have tested positive for COVID-19. Research now shows that infected mink may contract the virus from humans and can transmit SARS-CoV-2 back to humans. This cycle has led to the development of mutated strains of the virus. Wild mink have also tested positive for COVID-19 in Utah.

hypothesis: One in four Nigerians are suffering from some sort of mental illness.
explanation_1: The actual claim of 1 in 4 is not addressed in the source so I would need to see proof of that actual number rather than a percentage to support the claim.
speaker: Al Jazeera

answers.answer: A lot of people are suffering from mental health issues. We have challenges of poor identification, late recognition and therefore, limited funding. The result of it is that a lot of people who have mental issues suffer on their own, people don’t understand they are not feeling well

questions.question: Is there an exact ratio on the number of Nigerians that are suffering from some sort of mental illness?

answers.answer: With a population of 181 million, it is estimated that as much as 30 percent of the population suffers from a mental illness. This means that more than 54 million people are dealing with mental illness with little to no help. In comparison, the Center for Disease Control estimates that 54 million is the same number of people who are diagnosed with arthritis in the United States.

hypothesis: More than 500 scientists and professionals in climate and related fields have sent a "European Climate Declaration" to the Secretary-General of the United Nations.
explanation_1: Evidence shows that the 500 aren't even experts in climate change and according to a source the credibility is low
speaker: 500 scientists

answers.answer:
Amber Kerr, Researcher, Agricultural Sustainability Institute, University of California, Davis:
While reviewing the claims related to agriculture, I noted that only 26 out of the 506 signatories (5%) were professionals in biology, ecology, or environmental science. I suspect that the vast majority of signatories had little direct knowledge or understanding of this part of the petition that they signed.

questions.question: How many of the 500 signatures are scientists?

answers.answer: The most prevalent groups of signatories were geologists (19%) and engineers (21%)—many of whom were implicitly or explicitly involved in fossil energy extraction. Most of the rest were physicists, chemists, and mathematicians.

questions.question: What were the prevalent fields of expertise within the signatures?
How many signatures were not scientists?

answers.answer: Yes
answers.boolean_explanation: “Peter Champness, Radiologist, Australia”; “Patrick Mellett, architect and CEO”; and “Fintan Ryan, Retired Senior Airline Captain” (to say nothing of the dozens and dozens of fossil fuel employees)

questions.question: Were there any signatories with credentials?

answers.answer:
Amber Kerr, Researcher, Agricultural Sustainability Institute, University of California, Davis:
While reviewing the claims related to agriculture, I noted that only 26 out of the 506 signatories (5%) were professionals in biology, ecology, or environmental science. I suspect that the vast majority of signatories had little direct knowledge or understanding of this part of the petition that they signed.

questions.question: How many of the signatories are scientists?

answers.answer:
The Washington Times - Sunday, September 29, 2019 published an article on the event.

Scientists tell U.N. Global Climate Summit: No emergency

Climate Intelligence Foundation calls for UN meeting with experts from both sides of debate

 ....last week’s U.N. Global Climate Summit were the 500 international scientists, engineers and other stakeholders sounding a very different message: “There is no climate emergency.”

The signers asked Mr. Guterres to place the declaration on the UN’s agenda for the meeting ending Monday—which hasn’t happened—and organize a meeting of scientists “on both sides of the climate debate early in 2020.”

The Independent UK published on Wednesday 25 September 2019 :

Hundreds of climate change deniers including academics, politicians and lobbyists are to launch a campaign to stop commitments to net zero carbon emissions being enshrined in law, The Independent can reveal.

A letter titled “There is no climate emergency” – which has been signed by 400 people who deem climate change to be a myth – is being sent to leaders of European Union (EU) and United Nations (UN) institutions in the coming weeks ahead of key environment talks.

questions.question: What did the media report about the claim that more than 500 scientists and professionals in climate and related fields have sent a 'European Climate Declaration' to the Secretary-General of the United Nations.?

answers.answer: The European Climate Declaration was spearheaded by the Amsterdam-based Climate Intelligence Foundation [CLINTEL].

questions.question: Who was responsible for the declaration letter?

answers.answer: The letter has been criticized by six scientists who claim that its credibility is very low. One complaint is that most of the 500 are not experts in "climate science."

The letter uses the phrasing "more than 500 knowledgeable and experienced scientists and professionals in climate and related fields". Not all are "scientists" as per the title that the OP wrote. As seen above, one person is simply listed as being an "author" and another is listed as "PhD in Law, author of several books".

...the sheer number of prominent signers with scientific and engineering credentials belied the contention that only a handful of fringe researchers and fossil-fuel shills oppose the climate-catastrophe “consensus.”

The U.S. contingent was made up of 45 U.S. professors, engineers and scientists, including MIT professor emeritus Richard Lindzen; Freeman Dyson of the Institute of Advanced Studies at Princeton, and Stanford University professor emeritus Elliott D. Bloom, as well as several signers formerly affiliated with NASA.

hypothesis: US President Obama was ready to have gone to war with North Korea.
explanation_1: This claim is refuted. According to the QA pairs, President Obama's close aides said he was "never close to an attack" even when North Korea reported a nuclear test. President Obama reportedly said that a ground invasion of North Korea is "unthinkable". The claim states that he was "ready to go to war" and that clearly wasn't the case. Therefore, the claim is refuted.
speaker: US President Donald Trump
reporting_source: Press conference at the White House Rose Garden

answers.answer:
We were not on the brink of war with North Korea in 2016,” Benjamin J. Rhodes, Mr. Obama’s deputy national security adviser, wrote on Twitter.

John Brennan, Mr. Obama’s C.I.A. director, told NBC News, “President Obama was never on the verge of starting any war with North Korea, large or small.”

questions.question: Did Barack obamas cabinet have anything to say about the claim?

answers.answer: In his most recent book, Bob Woodward (Washington post) reported that after a North Korean nuclear test in September 2016, Mr. Obama asked if a surgical strike could take out the country’s arsenal, but after being told it would require a ground invasion, he rejected any action as “unthinkable.” His former aides say he never came close to ordering an attack.

questions.question: Were there any other reports about Obama wanting war?

premise:
Question 1:  Did Barack obamas cabinet have anything to say about the claim? 
Answer 1:  We were not on the brink of war with North Korea in 2016,” Benjamin J. Rhodes, Mr. Obama’s deputy national security adviser, wrote on Twitter.

John Brennan, Mr. Obama’s C.I.A. director, told NBC News, “President Obama was never on the verge of starting any war with North Korea, large or small.” 
 
Question 2:  Were there any other reports about Obama wanting war? 
Answer 2:  In his most recent book, Bob Woodward (Washington post) reported that after a North Korean nuclear test in September 2016, Mr. Obama asked if a surgical strike could take out the country’s arsenal, but after being told it would require a ground invasion, he rejected any action as “unthinkable.” His former aides say he never came close to ordering an attack.

hypothesis: Ghana’s two dominant political parties, the New Patriotic Party (NPP) and National Democratic Congress (NDC) are both laying claim to the Free Senior High School (SHS) programme, a social intervention project meant to improve access to education.
explanation_1: This claim is refuted. President Nana Akuffo-Addo started the Free SHS Policy, not Former president John Mahama.

answers.answer: The Free Secondary High School (Free SHS) education policy in Ghana was a government initiative launched by President Nana Akuffo-Addo in September 2017. The policy was part of Nana Addo’s campaign messages during Ghana's 2016 election period, and has become an essential part of Ghana's educational system. The policy's core themes of access, equity and equality fulfill the United Nations modified Sustainable Development Goals, where member countries amalgamate those themes in their educational systems to certify adequate learning experiences for students.

questions.question: Did  Former President John Mahama started the Free SHS Policy ?

premise:
Question 1:  Did  Former President John Mahama started the Free SHS Policy ? 
Answer 1:  The Free Secondary High School (Free SHS) education policy in Ghana was a government initiative launched by President Nana Akuffo-Addo in September 2017. The policy was part of Nana Addo’s campaign messages during Ghana's 2016 election period, and has become an essential part of Ghana's educational system. The policy's core themes of access, equity and equality fulfill the United Nations modified Sustainable Development Goals, where member countries amalgamate those themes in their educational systems to certify adequate learning experiences for students.

If we could change ourselves, the tendencies in the world would also change. As a man changes his own nature, so does the attitude of the world change towards

questions.question: What quote of Gandhi did Professor Bakker refer to which is thematically related?

answers.answer: This website records the investigatory work of Garson O’Toole who diligently seeks the truth about quotations. Who really said what? This question often cannot be answered with complete finality, but approximate solutions can be iteratively improved over time.

questions.question: What is the website Quote Investigator?

answers.answer:
Quote Investigator: Gandhi died in 1948, and the earliest close match known to QI appeared many years later in 1974 within a book chapter written by educator Arleen Lorrance. She described her unhappiness while employed at a high school in Brooklyn, New York:[1]
 ...be the change you want to see happen.

 ...be the change you want to see happen.

hypothesis: US Senator Amy Klobuchar said While we are all sitting here debating, Wisconsin has kicked hundreds of thousands of people off of their voting rolls
explanation_1: yes, wisconsin has removed people who didn't update their address details, but not random people, the answers showed no evidence that people were unlawfully removed.
speaker: Amy Klobuchar

answers.answer: Wisconsin appeals court rules voters targeted for purge will remain on the rolls

questions.question: Did the US state of Wisconsin purge hundreds of thousands of people off of their voting rolls in 2020

answers.answer:
The Wisconsin Elections Commission last month sent letters to voters who it believes may have moved. The letters told the recipients to update their voter registrations with their new addresses if they have moved or to notify the commission if they have not moved.

Those who don't act on the letters will have their voter registrations suspended after April 2021, according to the commission.

questions.question: Why did the Wisconsin Election Commission send letters to 234,000 voters warning them they may be removed from polls in 2021?

answers.answer:
A Wisconsin appeals court Friday struck down an Ozaukee County judge's ruling that thousands of people had to be quickly removed from the state's voter rolls because they are believed to have moved.

The appeals judges also unanimously overturned a finding that state election officials were in contempt of court for not taking people off the rolls.

questions.question: What did the Wisconsin court rule about the election commission?

premise:
Question 1:  Did the US state of Wisconsin purge hundreds of thousands of people off of their voting rolls in 2020 
Answer 1:  Wisconsin appeals court rules voters targeted for purge will remain on the rolls 
 
Question 2:  Why did the Wisconsin Election Commission send letters to 234,000 voters warning them they may be removed from polls in 2021? 
Answer 2:  The Wisconsin Elections Commission last month sent letters to voters who it believes may have moved. The letters told the recipients to update their voter registrations with their new addresses if they have moved or to notify the commission if they have not moved.

Those who don't act on the letters will have their voter registrations suspended after April 2021, according to the commission. 
 
Question 3:  What did the Wisconsin court rule about the election commission? 
Answer 3:  A Wisconsin appeals court Friday struck down an Ozaukee County judge's ruling that thousands of people had to be quickly removed from the state's voter rolls because they are believed to have moved.

The appeals judges also unanimously overturned a finding that state election officials were in contempt of court for not taking people off the rolls.

hypothesis: A no deal Brexit means no more ECJ or ECHR.
explanation_1: the answers show The UK will continue to be a member of the European Court of Human Rights after Brexit because its jurisdiction has nothing to do with the EU, but the UK would lose access to the european court of justice. so this is conflicting information.

answers.answer: Yes
answers.boolean_explanation:
The European Communities Act 1972 was the piece of legislation that brought the UK into the Europe Union: it gives EU law supremacy over UK national law.

A large amount of EU law effective in the UK currently relies on the 1972 Act.

The Act is repealed by the EU Withdrawal Act 2018

questions.question: Would a no deal Brexit remove the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice?

answers.answer:
The European Court of Human Rights, judicial organ of the Council of Europe,
examines applications from individuals, but also inter-State applications, lodged by
a State against another State party to the Convention. Currently 47 countries have
undertaken to secure fundamental rights and freedoms, not only to their nationals
but to everyone, even non-Europeans, within their jurisdiction.

questions.question: What is the European Court of Human Rights?

answers.answer: The Council of Europe (CoE) is a pan-European organisation of 46 member states, including all 27 member states of the European Union. The United Kingdom was one of the founding members. Set up shortly after the end of the Second World War, the CoE’s core mission is to promote human rights, democracy and the rule of law across the continent.

questions.question: What is the Council of Europe?

answers.answer: The UK will continue to be a member of the European Court of Human Rights after Brexit because its jurisdiction has nothing to do with the EU
No
answers.boolean_explanation: Even if the UK leaves the European Union, it is still a participant in the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR).

but to everyone, even non-Europeans, within their jurisdiction.

Set up shortly after the end of the Second World War, the CoE’s core mission is to promote human rights, democracy and the rule of law across the continent.
